title: Which cooking oil is the healthiest?

multiplechoice.text: What bonds are found in un/saturated oils?
multiplechoice.answer: saturated: single bonds, unsaturated: double bonds
answers: saturated: double bonds, unsaturated: single bonds
saturated: single bonds, unsaturated: single bonds
saturated: double bonds, unsaturated: double bonds

multiplechoice.text: Recent research has demonstrated that cooking has __ effect on the properties of extra virgin olive oil
Which type of fats is it preferable to eat more of?
Is olive oil a saturated or unsaturated fat?
Omega 3 and omega 6 are what kind of fat?
Carbon atoms in (hydrogen) saturated fats are connected to how many other atoms?
Unsaturated fats are distinguished from saturated fats by double bonds between __
answers: A carbon atom and a hydrogen atom
A carbon atom and an oxygen atom

multiplechoice.text: Trans fats have the effect of --
Trans fats are unsaturated fats with trans double bonds instead of cis bonds. What do trans and cis mean in this context?
multiplechoice.answer: Cis: functional groups on the same side as the carbon chain, trans: opposite sides
answers: Trans: functional groups on the same side as the carbon chain bond, cis: opposite sides

multiplechoice.text: What are the recommended upper limits for daily saturated fat consumption for men and women?
Hydrogenation of fat products is used in the food industry for what reason?
Harvard University’s TH Chan School of Public Health’s nutrition department found that those with higher intake of all types of olive oil had a ___ of heart disease

sources.author: Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health

unranked.text: Organic chemistry refers to the study of compounds that must contain which element?
Saturated fats are saturated in what?
Triglyceride or triacylglycerol is the technical term for what?
What does HDL stand for? (hint: contains a hyphen)
Polyunsaturated fats, such as omega 3 and omega 6, and monounsaturated fat provide essential fatty acids and ___?
What is the name for micronutrients derived from plants? (hint: plural)
In which organ are longer chain fatty acids more likely to be stored? (tip: one word)
In the article, efficacy in preventing several diseases is attributed to extra virgin olive oil. Name one
Which fats are unequivocally bad, and should be avoided, even in small amounts? (hint: two words)
What is the process by which unsaturated fats are turned into trans fats? (hint: __ or partial __)

cards.definition: Fatty acids are molecules that consist of a long chain of carbon and hydrogen atoms attached to a carboxyl group
A small, organic molecule formed of carbon and 3 hydroxyl groups (OH)

cards.term: What is a fat (triglyceride or triacylglycerol)?
cards.definition: A glycerol backbone to which 3 fatty acid 'tails' are attached

cards.term: What are the structures of fats (fatty acids), and how does this affect their function?
cards.definition: All fat molecules are made of chains of fatty acids, which are either held together with single bonds (saturated) or double bonds (unsaturated). There are three types of fatty acids: short, medium and long chain. Short and medium chain fatty acids are absorbed directly into the bloodstream and used for energy, but long chain fatty acids are transported to the liver, which raises blood cholesterol levels
An acid is a molecule that can donate a proton (hydrogen ion) to another substance, or form a covalent bond (by sharing of elections)

HDL clears from the body via the liver. HDL may therefore prevent the buildup of plaque, protect your arteries, and protect you from atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. It is considered the “good” cholesterol, and higher levels are better. A good goal to aim for is higher than 55 mg/dL for women and 45 mg/dL for men. The higher your HDL cholesterol numbers, the lower your risk is for heart disease, vascular disease, and stroke

HDL carries cholesterol to your arteries, where it may collect in the vessel walls and contribute to plaque formation, known as atherosclerosis. This can lead to decreased blood flow to the heart muscle (coronary artery disease), leg muscles (peripheral artery disease), or abrupt closure of an artery in the heart or brain, leading to a heart attack or stroke. Obesity, a large waist circumference, a sedentary lifestyle, or a diet rich in red meat, full-fat dairy, saturated fat, trans fats, and processed foods can lead to high LDL cholesterol

cards.term: Describe the benefit to human health of trans fats
cards.definition: Trans fats provide no benefits to human health and are not essential. There is no safe level of dietary trans fat. Trans fats help the food industry by extending shelf life and increasing the melting point of the hydrogenated fat

multipleselect.text: Which properties are true of trans fats?
answers: the functional groups are on opposite sides of the carbon chain
a trans bond creates a straight chain
trans fats are a result of partial hydrogenation
alternatives: hydrogenation decreases the fat’s melting point
trans fats have positive effects on human health

multipleselect.text: When olive oil is excluded, the Mediterranean diet shows 1 health benefit, and 1 health drawback compared to the Western diet. What are they?
Extra virgin olive oil is rich in:
Which is true in respect of monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFAs)?
answers: they have a single double bond
MUFAs are found in red meat, whole milk, nuts, and high fat fruits such as olives and avocados
MUFAs are generally healthier than saturated ones
alternatives: olive oil contains little monounsaturated fat

multipleselect.text: Which is true in respect of polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs)?
answers: they have two or more double bonds
PUFAs are found mostly in nuts, seeds, fish, seed oils, and oysters
alternatives: PUFAs are the most common fatty acids in the human diet

multipleselect.text: What is true of randomised controlled trials?
answers: they are used for testing the effectiveness of new treatments
subjects are randomly allocated to two or more groups, and treated differently in each
alternatives: the experimental group receives an alternative treatment, such as a placebo or no intervention
the control group receives the intervention being assessed

multipleselect.text: Which of the following are true about cholesterol?
answers: it is an essential structural component of animal cell membranes
alternatives: it cannot be synthesised by human cells

multipleselect.text: How does the structure of fats affect their properties?
answers: saturated fats are packed tightly and have a relatively high melting point
saturated fats are solid at room temperature
unsaturated fats are usully liquid at room temperature
alternatives: polyunsaturated fats are often solid at room temperature
olive oil is mostly made up of saturated fats

multipleselect.text: alpha-linolenic acid (ALA) and linolenic acid (LA) are essential fatty acids
answers: the human body cannot synthesise ALA or LA
salmon and chia are sources of ALA (omega-3)
alternatives: Omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids have at least two trans-unsaturated bonds

multipleselect.text: what are some of the benefits of fats?
answers: necessary for the absorption of vitamins
alternatives: contain less energy per gram than carbohydrates
